intro: Pentaphylloides fruticosa var. albicans, commonly known as the white-flowered mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its dense, evergreen foliage and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant produces small, fleshy berries that are typically yellow or orange in color. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in forested areas where suitable host trees are present. Its botanical features make it a distinctive and ecologically significant species in its native range.
